I take the point-----
What was Mr. Coffey's reaction when he saw these coming through? Did he see them coming through?
No, I did not see that material.
Why not?
My involvement was in a transition period between January and February this year, to full responsibility in March. From March onwards-----
Did Mr. Gleeson see any of this coming through?
Yes, over time.
Was Mr. Gleeson aware of the changes from P2 to P9 in some cases?
Yes.
Did this not alarm him?
We presented the findings to quality assurance, to pathologists and asked them to review them.
Did Mr. Gleeson not see a trend, in that a number of cases-----

No, we did not see a trend. They were not all done by the same screener on the same day or on the same test date. They are spread out over time, over different laboratories and over individual screeners-----
Mr. Gleeson did see a trend-----
----amid a huge number of tests.
So Mr. Gleeson did see a trend.
I did not see a trend.
Did anyone in the HSE see any trends?
That information would be specific to the audit, to the CervicalCheck programme and specific to-----
Surely the feedback was coming back through the organisation.
Not at that level of clinical detail. The CervicalCheck programme has a quality committee and it is the members of that committee who would see that type of information.
Are the witnesses aware that a number of the misdiagnoses are from 2011? It seems that I have more information on this than the HSE or CervicalCheck.
They are not misdiagnoses. They might be a missed opportunity for an early follow up but they are not misdiagnoses.
Well, we will not play with language. Why was the HSE's risk committee not informed of this as a potential risk?

The risk committee would only be informed that it was a potential risk if it was reviewing the risk register for the health and well being division. As was said earlier, risk management is led locally and is only escalated where further support outside of the organisation is required. The screening programme would have been looking at this audit as a control measure as opposed to a risk. At the time when it would have been looking at this, the audit was a control measure for quality assurance. There was not a risk in the audit. One would normally conduct an audit as a control measure to address a risk.
When the HSE became aware in 2017 about the issues around these women being told, was that not a risk?
Yes, but it was not escalated onto the risk register.
Why not?

It would appear that there was a failure in detecting the risk from concerns being raised and what that would mean for patients. I say that, having looked at all of the information that I have now. There was also a failure in escalating real evidence of risk as a result of the communications that I have seen. At the time in 2016, the audit would have been seen as a control measure and the risk pieces would not have changed throughout that.

For me, that is dysfunctional. I asked if the HSE directorate was made aware of these matters. The response I got was that it was not the purpose of the director to manage operational issues. In the context, it would not have expected to have been made aware of the issues regarding the CervicalCheck audit. We know that many members of the directorate were aware of it but it was not discussed at directorate meetings. The directorate is the senior management, effectively. Many of the people who are here today and others who are out of the country at present were aware of this issue but it was never discussed at directorate meetings.

It was never discussed at directorate meetings to the best of my knowledge. We have probably answered the wrong question there. My job previously was deputy director general of operations. I am in charge of the operational elements for the delivery of the health care system and I am part of the directorate.
It was not discussed. Is that right?
No, it was not discussed.
That is unbelievable. I also find it incredible that the minutes of the national planning oversight group, NPOG, meetings make no reference to it.

When it comes to the packages that are being made available to the 209 women, the HSE is not ready. I say this because its own people have told me so. I ask the witnesses to take that on board. Across the board, the HSE is not ready for this------
I have a slightly different versions of events having spoken to chief executives and the national director-----
Maybe Mr. Connaghan should go down the line.
Maybe I will.
Senator Keith Swanick made a very good point earlier. Is it the case that minutes of HSE directorate meetings are always prepared?
Yes.
On one occasion when the now Taoiseach, then Minister for Health, sat in on a meeting, there were no minutes.
Is that the meeting of 25 November?
It was 26 November.
Was it 26 November 2015?
Yes.
I really cannot account for that. I do not know why there were no minutes. I only suspect that it might well have been informal.

If it was informal, it was a long informal meeting. His next diary appointment was over three hours later. Will the delegates go back, once and for all, so we can cut out all this rubbish and find out whether there are minutes, notes or anything else to do with that meeting? Could they also confirm the position in writing? In fairness to Senator Swanick, he determined it was the only meeting that has never been minuted. It was a meeting between the Minister for Health and the director of the HSE. These meetings are all minuted, obviously; we have seen some of these. It looks like the meeting in question was the only meeting that was never minuted. I accept everything the Secretary General has said on the Department and knowledge of Ministers but the meeting was the only one at which we do not know what was spoken about. It happened to be the one with the then Minister for Health. Will the delegates please come back to me on that because Senator Swanick deserves a response?

One of the things that is worth clarifying is whether the convention of the HSE when the Minister attended a meeting was to minute it. It tended to be a more informal meeting and was not a full directorate meeting. I am not certain that this was the only one of those meetings. We minuted the ones in the Department. We supplied a secretariat. The HSE is looking into that and will come back on it.
It can come back but my point is that it is still a fact that this is the only meeting that was not minuted.

With regard to a final run-around, I still do not understand why Dr. Holohan did not tell the Minister, Deputy Harris, about the audit documents and why he did not know about them before they were pulled out here last Thursday. The explanation for that has not been forthcoming.

We have already been asked that question. The answer is that when we became aware, the Minister's focus and our focus was exactly the same, that was, to establish the facts, get on top of the issue and try to manage as best we could. I was directly involved in establishing the senior incident management team, establishing the information that came to light over the weekend when that senior incident management team established that there were 46 cases out of 208. That information all came out on a Sunday evening. Leading on from that, it was a matter of establishing the true facts of the situation, which, unfortunately, became clear only shortly before Dáil statements on the Tuesday evening, which I am sure Deputy Alan Kelly can recall, and, over the course of that week, trying to shape and put into place the scoping inquiry, the clinical audit process and all those kinds of arrangements. The focus was to manage it. As I said earlier, our job, as we see it, was not to push materials up the line per se.
Does Dr. Holohan believe he should have told him about them? From conversation, I believe he thinks Dr. Holohan should have.
On the content, we were well aware-----
I understand that. The response is a "Yes" or "No". Dr. Holohan can say "No". Does he believe he should have given him the documents?
I do not believe we should have spent our time in the Department sifting through documents that were two years old instead of managing the issue-----
They are the most revealing documents-----
No, they do not reveal anything more than that the HSE was preparing to conduct a clinical audit-----
I disagree.
The Deputy may disagree but-----

I disagree with him in a reasonable way because what they did was open avenues for us to consider regarding how the HSE handled the matter, how it was being communicated, and legal issues. A range of different things were brought out and evolved because of that.

From our point of view, the sum total of information that those documents confirmed was the understanding we had and operated upon, which we would have shared with the Minister. We were in a position to give assurance that our understanding was only that auditing was taking place and that disclosure was happening. That was our understanding; that was our briefing so we turned our focus to getting into a place and managing the response to his-----
I am sure Minister Harris is watching this.

-----and putting the Government in a place where it could respond to this and do so effectively by establishing the scoping inquiry and the clinical audit process. There were three memos brought to the Government by the Minister, Deputy Harris, over that time period-----
Sorry to be rude but I have to-----
The focus was managing and responding and not passing information around.

Regarding the documents or memos that Mr. Gleeson drafted and that were signed by Dr. O'Keeffe, did he give them to Dr. O'Keeffe for observation? Did she change them in any way? Did she make any alterations to any of his documents?
They were not only my documents. I created them, signed them and sent them on through the head of the screening service.
Yes. Did Dr. O'Keeffe make any changes to them?
She may have made comments that would have been worthwhile in finalising them. I cannot recall but I would have signed the final one.
Please find out and forward them.
I do not believe she did. She would have made comments and I would have taken them on board, but I do not remember any changes.
She did not make any changes. That is important.
What is the legal firm that was employed? Mr. Connaghan said earlier he hired a legal team.
I do not have that name but I can supply it.

I want to make a suggestion to Mr. John Connaghan because I obviously raised issues with him that I am concerned about. Has somebody in his organisation been tasked with securing and locking down all data and records, electronically and otherwise, across the organisation?
Yes.
Good. I do not need to know who it is but I just want confirmation that it is happening.
I would need to understand the definition of "lock down" but-----
In other words, it is so people will not delete stuff to cover their backsides.
We can always find that out. We can do-----
One would be surprised. We had the gardaí in here a number of times.
Okay.

I was the person who asked National Cancer Registry Ireland to come here. I have three more questions. I cannot understand what is going on between CervicalCheck and the National Cancer Registry. The Minister was let down badly in the way he had to be provided with the information. I refer to the facts that there was a lack of knowledge of this in the Department and that it was told information that turned out be wrong. That it was not known in the first place was crazy but it was told wrong information. Let me get this right. When it comes to BreastCheck, the form is signed by the registry and the information is two ways.
Correct.
Thanks for the brevity. When it comes to CervicalCheck, it is signed but it is only one way.
Correct.
For how long has Cancer Registry Ireland or CervicalCheck been trying to get this information to match? I am not trying to catch anyone out here because I believe there were genuine efforts.

I was not the director at the time but the registry signed a 2011 one-year agreement with CervicalCheck, and that allowed us to have access to its online system. Some discussions began on how to exchange information. My understanding of it – there is no documentation of it that I found – was that there were data protection issues that came into play to block that, meaning that we could not give the data back in some way.
Does anyone from CervicalCheck wish to give its version of the story? I am not trying to catch the witnesses out because I believe there are other issues here.

I concur with what Professor Clough-Gorr has said. It was also on the understanding that, at a point in the future, National Cancer Registry Ireland, as it is a separate legal entity from the HSE, might or might not continue or might be integrated into the NCCP, so that barrier was going to be-----

Ultimately, data protection issues were the reason. This is a big concern. This is important. Data protection issues are the reason we have two different databases. We know from Dr. Hickey's correspondence that there are issues with the internal databases within CervicalCheck. The two sets of databases could not talk because of data protection. Is that an appropriate summary?
Yes.
What efforts were made over the years? I would say efforts were made. How could they not be concluded? Was the Department of Health aware of this issue? My question is for by delegates.

To the best of my knowledge, we have gone through all the records we could find at the registry. There was no elevation of this particular issue to the Department of Health. It was between CervicalCheck and the registry. My understanding from the previous director is that it was a very clear data protection ruling that no data could be given back.
Why did the registry not elevate it to the Department?
I do not know. I cannot answer that.
May I make a suggestion? Both organisations said this is the law. There are other agencies in the same vein that cannot share information----
No. I am sorry but this is deeper than that, Chairman.
Okay.

Can I make just one point to add to this which may explain some of the hiatus? As the Deputy is aware, the Government published the national cancer strategy last year. The steering group deliberated on that and developed that over about a two-year period. I was on that as well as Professor Harry Comber. There was a lot of discussion about the best way to organise cancer data to give access. There was discussion, recommendations in the final document and an aspiration to improve systems, but that is what was happening in that two-year period.

Dr. Coffey can understand and appreciate that for people watching this meeting, and, trust me, thousands of people are watching it, even up to this hour, the idea that National Cancer Registry Ireland, which reports directly to the Department, and CervicalCheck, which comes through the Health Service Executive, HSE, and up to the Department, could not get its act together across data protection issues is a laugh. We do not know yet the problems this has caused. In fairness, I do not expect the witnesses to know but this will cause problems. I guarantee that when this report is done, this will have caused problems. That is absolute incompetence at some level somewhere.
I seek information. Is there two-way transfer in the BowelScreen?
There is no transfer at all with BowelScreen.
So we are doing this all over again. Are the witnesses going to sort that out?

As I understand it, there is no audit process in place as yet and when it is, discussions will happen. To clarify, I have asked the Minister for a two-way data transfer agreement with the HSE entirely that will cover all this.
When did Professor Clough-Gorr ask him?
When we did the specific use for here, and I brought it up before since the general data protection regulation, GDPR, has become an issue.
In the past few weeks.
No. It was brought up many times in regard to GDPR and again here.

I want to make a prediction. In a previous life I spent four years building a database; that is a different story. Professor Clough-Gorr has not got permission from the people who have already gone through. She has not got two-way permission.
For CervicalCheck?
No. For BowelScreen.
We do not have anything at all with them, nothing.
That is even worse.
They are not doing auditing or they have not come up in our discussions.
Wait a second. There will be auditing.
Yes, probably.
There is individual consent at that stage. I would just say to the Deputy that this is the current data protection legislation.
Exactly.
When GDPR comes in next week-----
Exactly.
-----they will not even be allowed talk to the person on the computer beside them in their office.
Do not get me started.
I think the problem-----
As a former MEP, I am embarrassed by that.
It is our fault as legislators.
As a former MEP I would say it is at a different level, but we are responsible too.

Dr. Henry and Dr. McKenna are aware of all these documents to which I am referring. In fairness, without me even raising it, they spoke to another Deputy earlier about when they became aware of the issues. I say to Mr. Connaghan that I wish Mr. Woods and Mr. Lynch were here so we could round the circle as regards who knew what. In fairness to Dr. Henry, it appears he made some efforts to try to escalate this matter. Dr. McKenna was aware of this. It is good to have these documents, which are published now on the Committee of Public Accounts website, but reading them would be incomprehensible to normal people. Vicky Phelan is watching this meeting, and there are families out there watching it, and they do not understand why somebody did not just shout "Stop". I say genuinely to Mr. Connaghan that directors were aware of this. At directorate level, Mr. Woods and Mr. Lynch were aware of it. If I remember rightly, Mr. Woods said he referred it to Dr. O'Keeffe. I would like to see a copy of that document because we do not have a copy of it so I would appreciate it if it were supplied it to the committee.
We will make a note of that.
Please do.
A copy of?
Mr. Woods said earlier that he referred it across to Dr. O'Keeffe; they are at the same level.
He referred what to me?
The letter on which he was copied on 13 July 2017.
No. He did not refer that on to me.
Who did he refer it on to?
I thought he said-----
We might check that. Maybe we can go back on the record.
Did he say he referred it on to Dr. Henry?
You can check that and get a copy sent to us.
Will Mr. Connaghan ask Mr. Woods who he referred it on to as we now do not know? I would like a copy stating who he referred it on to because we do not know that.
Certainly. We also need to check the record as regards what exactly was said.

I agree with Mr. Connaghan because if we cannot remember it shows something. This is not to catch out either of the witnesses because that is not what I am trying to do here. I refer to all of this correspondence, which all of Ireland can digest now. I presume that when this was escalated from the actual hospital and, to be fair, the hospital CEO, Mr. Burke, moved it on, and I would like to know what all the other general managers in hospitals did, in hindsight it was obvious from the letter on 22 August from Dr. Kevin Hickey to Gráinne Flannelly, on which Dr. Henry and Dr. McKenna were copied, that he is fairly annoyed. Instead of saying what was happening, he says it is totally inappropriate. What I really want to know is that, regarding the actions or non-actions that happened afterwards, do they believe something different from what did happen should have happened?
There is correspondence after it because I wrote back to Professor Flannelly after that letter.
It is in here. We have it.

Yes, and I told her that the situation was that the clinician in Limerick remained dissatisfied and that what she had said was not in harmony with what he understood. She replied to me on 8 September stating-----
We have that one.

On foot of that she had a meeting with clinicians and assured me on 8 September that she had listened to their concerns, apologised for the communication difficulties and was going to change things. I am a clinician and, working in my clinical world, when a senior clinician, whether it is a general practitioner or a consultant, tells me that they are going to do something, I presume they will follow through on that. I do not believe I have to assure myself that they will go ahead and do what they actually said they were going to do. I was in here not just as senior clinician but as somebody who is medical director of the service.
I know, and I am genuinely not having a go at Dr. Henry but this had been moved across to the directorate. They were well aware of it. Surely somebody somewhere should have followed up on this.
I was not aware. The only awareness I had was the communication I got directly from the clinical director and the CEO of the University Hospital Limerick hospital group.
I know, but when this was put across, and Dr. Henry worked with the director of acute-----
Yes.
-----he was basically working for him.
Yes. I was a clinical adviser. That is correct.

As I understand it, nothing happened at acute hospital level for 15 months. Dr. Hickey then elevated it within the hospital. They had not any idea about this because as we now know from Dr. O'Keeffe, they were not copied on the 16 June documentation. To be fair, they did not know about it, which is amazing. The seven group hospital managers in the country were not made aware of it. Does Dr. Henry not feel that as an adviser to the acute directorate there should have been some form of follow-up? This had to be escalated. If there was such a concern in one hospital group, and we see from the letters that they were deeply concerned, surely at management level, and I know Dr. Henry is on the clinical side, there should have been a follow-up action. If Mr. Woods was here we would ask him, but he is not.

As I stated to the Deputy in another joint committee, if I had known that patients were not going to be told, I certainly would have pursued it more. If I had known it was such a significant, I would have pursued it more. At that time, I was taking assurances from someone who is a senior clinician and medical director of the service who told me in correspondence that if any doubt existed, she believed it was the correct thing that people should be told and informed me that she herself was telling patients.
The clinical director.
Of the cervical programme, yes. She wrote that-----

Yes, we have that. It is a famous letter at this stage. I wish Mr. Woods was present because I do not understand why there was no follow-up at the acute level. I am saying that to Mr. Connaghan directly. Sorry - I meant Dr. McKenna.
I agree. I wish we had followed it through, but we were of the understanding that the meeting between the programme and the colposcopists had sorted the matter out.
This famous September meeting.
Yes.

There was an October version of it as well, but it was not minuted. Can someone follow up on that, please? How in the name of God could there have been a meeting that was not minuted? It sounds suspicious to me. I am not getting at Dr. McKenna, but he understood that the programme and the colposcopists were having a meeting.
Yes, to sort it out.
As it turned out, the meeting was really to design a brochure,-----
I was of the understanding-----
-----if one breaks it all down.
Yes. I was of-----
Is that not frightening?

To put this into context, we were not aware of the fact that this had been rumbling for 18 months beforehand. This is something that we came in on and believed could be sorted out readily enough. I was of the belief that when the programme and colposcopists met and the programme communicated that the matter had been sorted out, it was.
When the programme told Dr. McKenna that there would be a meeting to sort it out, he believed it would be. Since he thought it had been sorted, he did not feel that there was a need to follow it up.
I followed it up with a phone call, when I was reassured that-----
What date?
I cannot recall.
I will not stick Dr. McKenna to a date, but how far was it past this meeting?
I imagine it would have been after the second meeting.
The October meeting.
Yes.

I find it bizarre. The minutes of this meeting are important, yet so many people did not even bother to partake that there were no minutes of the next meeting. The first meeting called was the September meeting. People came together because of this issue - let us call a spade a spade - but there are still no minutes of the follow-up meeting because it is obviously such a damning issue. I thank Dr. McKenna for his answers.

Deputy Kelly has covered much of this but, on the same thread, I wish to discuss the letter from Professor Burke of July 2017 to Professor Colette Cowan, which was copied to Dr. Henry. I will read two parts of that for the record, as they are important:
speech.blockquote:
... the guidelines outlined do appear to put an undue onus on the treating clinician rather than the screening programme to communicate directly with the patient in cases where the audit process has led to a change in the diagnosis. This then compels the treating Gynaecologists to engage in open disclosure with the patient Re the initial Cytology findings.
This has the potential to implicate the local treating consultant and his or her institution in what constitutes a missed diagnosis. The consequences of this could obviously have potential negative consequences for both the consultant and the institution.
speech.p: Obviously, this is referring to legal recourse for patients. That is what it is all about. This letter was sent nearly a year ago. Without being prejudicial towards anyone, everyone was covering his or her ass from a legal perspective and the patient was not central to the considerations. Everyone felt that he or she was doing his or her role, but critical links in the chain were not. We know who they are. It is not possible to compel a private citizen to appear before us, but it would be useful if the former clinical director were contacted to see whether she would like to join us.
Agreed. I second that.
We will discuss that after the meeting.
It is a good suggestion. I could suggest many more people.
It would be helpful, particularly given what Dr. O'Keeffe has said several times about one person being missing who might be able to fill in some of the gaps.

According to the various memos on the audit development process, including the February one, the State Claims Agency was consulted. Was it consulted along the way? Was it in the loop? Was there any advice from it as to how the HSE should handle matters legally?
I was told that the State Claims Agency was in the loop. Mr. Gleeson might comment.
There was one meeting with the clinical risk section of the State Claims Agency. I do not know its full title. It had nothing to do with legal matters, but with an assessment of risk.
Would the agency have ventured any advice such as "Yes, absolutely"?
In relation to the legal side, no.
No advice at all.
It was not a meeting with the agency's legal side. It was with the agency's head of clinical risk, who gave advice on how we would categorise these incidents.
The agency's whole function is legal.
This matter arose at yesterday's meeting of the health committee. One of the points that I-----
I did not get to my question at all. What does Mr. Breslin think I am asking?
One of the points I offered at the committee, which would help in this context,-----
Okay. Throw it out there.

-----is that risk management is within the functions of the State Claims Agency. It advised that the health service had good risk management practice. As well as managing legal claims, the agency seeks to promote a safety culture and management of risk.

When it appeared before us, I asked a question about cases. According to Mr. Breen, the figure was approximately 50%. In cases that were settled without admission of liability, the State Claims Agency had no role in recommending, or were not aware of whether there was, follow-up monitoring or training in respect of positions or practitioners who may have been associated with those cases. Will Mr. Breslin confirm whether that is the case?
I can confirm that that is what the agency told the committee last week.
Can Mr. Breslin confirm that it is the case in reality?
In the HSE?
Yes.
Maybe someone from the executive will comment on that.

Let us say that there was a gynaecological complaint and a child born with cerebral palsy goes to court and wins without an admission of liability. Are the relevant physicians associated with that case subject to any ongoing process of retraining or monitoring by a superior or peer? The State Claims Agency does not recommend it, which seems to be a failure on the risk management side in terms of helping the HSE along, future patient safety and good practice. Will the executive shed some light on this?

I am not sure if there is a written policy in that respect, but in any health jurisdiction, one would normally expect there to be something whereby, if someone was not appropriately deploying his or her skills, those needed updating or the person was not using best practice, a period of training would be required.

I am like Mr. Connaghan, in that I would expect that. I am conscious that he and Mr. McCallion are new brooms and I wish them well in their positions, but I have reason to believe that there is nothing written down and there is no protocol. For example, the Carpenter family received a settlement last week or the week before after a much-celebrated ten weeks of mediation, which followed five years of litigation. That was settled without admission of liability. I wonder whether nurses, registrars, consultants, administrators and so on are subject to a process of monitoring and retraining and whether protocols or policies in that regard are written down.

That is a good question. In many ways, it is at the heart of some of the matters we have been discussing at this meeting. Ms Rosarii Mannion has been present for seven or eight hours. She will have in her mind some knowledge of the operation of the disciplinary procedure. I wonder whether I might call on her to give some real life examples of how that works.
I do not want to drag this out, and I am sorry that Ms Mannion did not get to speak all day. I am sure she is delighted.
I would say that everyone else would be fine with her speaking now.
It is fine. Do not worry about it. No offence taken.

I do not necessarily want case-by-case examples, but the State Claims Agency stated that approximately 50% of cases were settled without admission of liability. With a "Yes" or "No" answer, is there an official procedure of monitoring and retraining those individuals?
Yes, there is.
Is that in every case?

It is the performance management system that we have signed up to in three successive national agreements. Every employee in the organisation is subject, or should be subject, to a performance management system.
Is that not more of an annual appraisal situation?

It is not. In terms of our people strategy - the issue of culture has come up over the course of the day - we firmly believe that leadership and culture drives everything with regard to safer, better healthcare. There is a specific section in that strategy on leadership accountability. It is more than just words in a document. There is an action plan on how we will implement accountability and performance management. The Sláintecare report, which we will hopefully be moving ahead with, will allow us to land that accountability piece across the organisation.

That is out there in the future and I am more interested in the heretofore. It is great we will have all these things in the future but I am concerned with the here and now. Let us use the Carpenter case as an example. I do not know what physicians were involved. They are not named in any cases I have seen. Are the various people associated with that case now subject to monitoring, retraining or supervision as a result of their proximity to a case in which there was a problem, albeit there was no admission of liability?
I will come back to Dr. McKenna.

My understanding is the relevant clinical director in the given area would be aware of it and would ensure appropriate supports are in place, mentoring or reskilling, whatever the case may be. I am happy to look into this specific case and give the Deputy feedback-----
I was only giving it as an example. It is not because I am from Sligo. It is because it was in the news lately.

In the course of my career I have engaged the National Clinical Advisory Service, NCAS, in Northern Ireland to come in and provide appropriate supports for individual consultants as the case may be. My understanding is there would be supports in place but I am happy to look into the Deputy's specific example.

Supports and protocol for supervision and monitoring for a period are two different things. A clinical director is unlikely to ring a colleague who he plays golf with on a Saturday saying: "Listen John, I know you were associated with that case where there was a settlement without admission of liability and here is what I think we need to do with you." I think that is unlikely to happen and I am concerned.

If there is a clinical issue with a consultant and the Medical Council is examining the issue, although it is entirely confidential, it would go to the High Court under section 60 and we would be notified and appropriate mitigation measures would be put in place.

The question is, and perhaps somebody can ask this to the State Claims Agency, with regard to the 50% of cases that are settled without admission of liability in the past 12 months, could we get an outline of what protocol was engaged in terms of supervision, monitoring, retraining and whatever, if necessary?
Dr. McKenna wanted to add something.

My real job is with the women and infants programme and the obstetric settlements account for about half of the State Claims Agency payouts so I have some familiarity with what happens to a large chunk of its money. I am not aware personally of any actions following on from a settlement done by the State Claims Agency on any individual.
When Mr. McKenna refers to nobody taking an action against an individual, does he mean a legal action?
No.
Is Dr. McKenna saying he is not aware of any monitoring supervision or retraining for any relevant personnel associated with cases he is familiar with on the gynaecological side?
I personally cannot recall one.

I suggest we are learning a big lesson here, which is that settlement without admission of liability seems to constitute a financial out for the State but it may not represent best practice in terms of avoiding a repetition of the same instance. I have no medical training. From a common sense perspective, we need a policy on it and a demonstrative thing that without admission of liability everyone associated with the case will go through this programme so we are-----
I support the Deputy on that point. We would want a detailed note from the HSE-----
I am not finished yet.

----and the State Claims Agency. The learning process is what Deputy MacSharry is talking about and preventing issues arising. If it is not happening it is a big problem and I understood here over previous years that there was a process of seeing what lessons could be learned. I understood that.
I am happy to follow it up.
Ms Mannion will not be able to do it on her own.
She can do it with the State Claims Agency. Ms Mannion will come back to us.

There will need to be an holistic approach with all the boxes joined. I am sure it will be resisted by clinicians but for their own protection and for that of the patients, we should put the patients at the centre rather than the limitation of the financial settlement.

We also need to describe in that response what the most basic level of feedback is with regard to cases. My experience is there is regular case review particularly where there are adverse cases in a multidisciplinary team. There are arrangements where one looks back, discusses the case and decides whether or not the action taken was appropriate. What we probably need to do is start at that most basic level because if we get it right there it solves problems for later on as well as going up a ladder.

It would be good practice. I know it is completely different but if a bank employee is in an armed robbery he or she goes through essential counselling. If I am associated with something that did not work out that well, it is reasonable that there would be appropriate action.

I have a couple more questions. It has been an awful long day for the witnesses and I do not want to delay them too much longer. The question to do with the State Claims Agency that led us off on that tangent was whether it ventured any advice on the timing of informing patients. Did it say they should definitely be informed? Did it say tell them as quickly as possible, do not tell them, cool the jets, hasten slowly or anything along those lines in terms of its input into it? What weighting was that given? I suppose Mr. Gleeson and Dr. O'Keeffe are the ones who can answer that question. It is important. It might inform further questioning of the State Claims Agency by us and particularly the weighting that is given to their advice in such a situation. Is it about the money or the patient, as we have seen at times that it has been?

I asked at the last meeting that we would be given a copy of the contract with the labs. The Department of Finance standard position on things like this is that it is commercially sensitive information. I hate that expression. I would ask for a copy of the contract to be sent to us and if the commercially sensitive information is the price, redact the price and send us the rest because there are other aspects of it we are very interested in looking at.

The State Claims Agency answered this question last week but as Mr. Gleeson is present and had some knowledge of the contracts I will ask him. I had asked whether the contract, as it is written, gives any recourse to the State in terms of the potential to pursue the laboratory for the very costly fallout from this part from the indemnity to the patient.
I do not know.

With respect, that is a question that I would like to place in front of our legal adviser. Let us not just have a go at answering the question tonight. Let us just take it away and we will give the Deputy a solid answer on it which is legally sound.

In fairness to the State and the people, this is all costing a lot of money. The witnesses are here all day today and all week in various committees and will be again I am sure. There is also the issue of the cost of redress, Dr. Scally and the commission of investigation. We are looking at big money. I would like to see if there is a potential case for us to pursue because if there is let us get it under way.
We are nearly there.

I am nearly there. To conclude, private citizens are not compelled to come here. They may not want to be but I think we would be abdicating our responsibility if we did not extend an invitation to the former head of CervicalCheck to come before us. I thank everybody for what has been a very long day.
Dr. Holohan wants to make a final remark.

I want to comment on what Deputy MacSharry was talking about. I do not want to take away from the question he asked about the State Claims Agency and the follow-on in terms of settlements and so on. To give a wider context, there is an incident management framework. Incidents are logged. They should be logged in real time and there should be a response to each one. Not everyone will require a significant investigation but depending on the severity there should be a response and there should be learning. That should be happening much more in real time. That does not take away in any sense but I wanted to provide that context.
There should be follow-up training. If one has been associated, albeit without liability, there should be a mandatory programme one must go through.
I will ask Mr. Connaghan to conclude.
This my first appearance before the committee.
Yes.

I thank the members for their candour. We have tried to answer as much as we possibly can. We will take some lessons away from this meeting about the written material the members need and about getting it to them in good order in the future. I thank the committee.
I thank Mr. Connaghan and extend best wishes to him in his role.

I hope Mr. Connaghan has taken away a lot more than what he just said. I would be absolutely devastated for the people I represent, for Vicky Phelan and Stephen Teap, if Mr. Connaghan only took away from this meeting what he just said.
An apology is nothing if it is simply words but is not backed up actions.
What about accountability?

I am concluding now. As Mr. Connaghan is probably aware, the HSE and the State Claims Agency are scheduled to appear before the committee before the summer recess. There is a long-standing commitment precisely to discuss issues such as medical negligence and the State Claims Agency bill of €2.5 million. It is not all attributable to the HSE. That is already on the agenda as part of a discussion of the 2017 financial statements, which, as the Comptroller and Auditor General said, Mr. Connaghan will probably have to put his signature to next week - or today or tomorrow, as he said it would be in the next day or so - because that normally happens at this time of year. Mr. Connaghan will be back here on that matter in the normal course of events.
Obviously, we will have to have other witnesses in as well.
Of course, and we will discuss that as part of our work programme.

We will adjourn until our next public meeting, which will be on Wednesday, 23 May. I thank the witnesses from the Department of Health, the HSE, the Medical Council and the National Cancer Registry and the Comptroller and Auditor General for attending. The meeting is now adjourned.
The committee adjourned at 6. 35 p.m. until 5 p.m. on Wednesday, 23 May 2018.

publicwhip.major-heading: Joint Oireachtas Committee on Finance, Public Expenditure and Reform, and Taoiseach

speech.p: The Joint Committee met at 10:00
MEMBERS PRESENT:
Deputy John Deasy, Senator Paddy Burke, Deputy Pearse Doherty, Senator Rose Conway-Walsh, Deputy Michael McGrath, Senator Kieran O'Donnell.
In attendance: Deputy Marc MacSharry.
DEPUTY JOHN MCGUINNESS IN THE CHAIR.
We are now in public session. We will go into private session to deal with a number of matters.
The committee went into private session at 10.05 a.m. and resumed in public session at 10.38 a.m.

We are now back in public session. I welcome Dr. Martha O'Hagan-Luff and Mr. Brendan Burgess to the meeting. We will be joined later by Mr. David Hall. We had intended to have three separate sessions for each submission but maybe it can be done in one session. We will leave an opening statement to be made by each witness.

I wish to advise the witnesses that by virtue of section 17(2)(l) of the Defamation Act 2009, witnesses are protected by absolute privilege in respect of their evidence to the committee. However, if they are directed by the committee to cease giving evidence on a particular matter and they continue to so do, they are entitled thereafter only to a qualified privilege in respect of their evidence. They are directed that only evidence connected with the subject matter of these proceedings is to be given and they are asked to respect the parliamentary practice to the effect that, where possible, they should not criticise or make charges against any person, persons or entity by name or in such a way as to make him, her or it identifiable.

Members are reminded of the long-standing parliamentary practice to the effect that they should not comment on, criticise or make charges against a person outside the House or an official either by name or in such a way as to make him or her identifiable.
We will begin our meeting with Dr. O'Hagan-Luff's opening statement, before hearing from Mr. Burgess.

I thank the Chairman and members for the invitation to present to the committee this morning. Specifically, I was asked to consider the potential benefits and risks of selling non-performing loans to private investment funds. As we know, many years after the financial crisis Irish banks continue to have very high ratios of non-performing loans to assets. Although the ratio has fallen from a high of 32% to just above 11%, it is still very high in comparison to the European average of 4.6%, and is one of the highest in Europe. This remains a source of vulnerability facing the domestic banking system. For the banks holding non-performing loans, this reduces their profitability, increases their funding costs and ties up bank capital, which has a negative impact on the supply of new credit and borrowing rates, and ultimately creates a drag on economic growth.

Many measures have been implemented in Ireland to reduce these ratios, one of which is the sale of non-performing loans to investment funds. The volume of distressed loan sales in Europe remains very low compared to the US market, but has begun to increase in recent years. A private investment fund can only raise funds from qualified and accredited investors. It cannot solicit funds from retail investors or from the general public. Such funds' regulatory and legal requirements are much lower than for funds that are accessible to retail investors, and this gives the funds greater freedom in how they handle aspects of their business. They have a very different business model from retail banks. Their time horizon for return on investment is relatively short and they seek higher short-term returns in contrast to the lower long-term returns sought by banks. I have been asked to outline the pros and cons, as I see them, of banks selling non-performing loans to private investors. These loans may be commercial property loans, business loans, buy-to-let or residential mortgages.

I will first outline the potential benefits. Allowing the sale of distressed loans to private investment funds may facilitate debt restructuring to be done more actively and more efficiently. Private funds will have greater flexibility in the resolution of non-performing loans. In the case of a renegotiated loan involving the voluntary surrender of a property, private funds will have more freedom to allow debt forgiveness on the outstanding loan, which is difficult for banks to do. In this scenario, it is possible that customers may be able to negotiate a better deal with a fund than they would be able to do with a bank. Finally, private funds can offer badly needed liquidity to banks for non-performing loans, which is not otherwise available.

However, there are also risks. Loans may be sold too cheaply. This will depend on how much liquidity exists in the market and this will be for banks to negotiate. There are concerns around consumer protection. As the private investment funds are unregulated, they do not fall under the remit of the Central Bank. However, under legislation introduced in 2015, if loans are sold they must be serviced by a credit servicing firm, which must be authorised and regulated by the Central Bank. As such, it will be subject to the same consumer protection legislation as banks. However, even when consumer protection regulations are adhered to, there may still be reputational risk for banks if funds are perceived to be acting aggressively or unreasonably with their former customers.

Finally, there is a potential risk of an increase in forced repossessions, although there has been little evidence to support this to date. Research by the UCC economist, Mr. Seamus Coffey, has shown that the rate of repossessions of family homes and buy-to-lets in Ireland is extremely low compared to our EU counterparts. At the time of his report, Mr. Coffey found that since 2010 repossessions accounted for only 1.4% of mortgages and the rate of repossession by private funds was lower than that by banks.

While it is essential that the most vulnerable in society are protected through schemes such as the mortgage to rent scheme and that high standards of consumer protection are ensured, I will conclude by summarising what I see as the risks of not resolving the issue of high levels of non-performing loans in Irish banks. It delays the resolution of non-performing loans with borrowers. It creates an issue of moral hazard around mortgage repayments, by which I mean that there is less incentive for current and future borrowers to abide by the terms of a contract if the contract is unlikely to be enforced. Secured lending is not secured in reality if repossession continues to be such a lengthy and difficult process and this risks creating a dysfunctional mortgage market. This would lead to a lower supply of new credit and higher interest rates than would otherwise be the case for the market as a whole in the future.

I apologise to Mr. David Hall. Things changed a bit this morning. Dr. O'Hagan-Luff has just concluded her opening statement. We will now hear the opening statement from Mr. Burgess. We will then go to Mr. Hall.

I would like to look at the bigger picture. As legislators, it is absolutely incumbent on committee members to look at the bigger picture when considering mortgage issues, mortgage arrears, vulture funds or personal insolvency legislation. The biggest number is that there are 300,000 borrowers, citizens of this State, who are paying the highest mortgage rates in Europe. I have been campaigning on this issue for a number of years. The response of the banks, the Central Bank, the Department of Finance and everybody else is to point to the high levels of arrears and non-performing loans in Ireland to justify charging extra. I do not accept that excuse is an explanation for all of it. It is an explanation for part of it. However, if we want to protect the vast majority of responsible borrowers, it is absolutely essential to allow the banks to deal with the very small percentage - about 2%, roughly 10,000 borrowers - who are not prepared to pay their mortgage. If I do not pay my mortgage, then Dr. O'Hagan-Luff and Mr. Hall will be asked to pay it for me. I do not get free accommodation. It is free to me, but somebody else pays it for me.

There are 24,000 borrowers who have been arrears for more than two years and 10,000 borrowers have been in arrears for more than five years. These are recent Central Bank figures. This would not be tolerated anywhere else. It is an extraordinarily high level of arrears. The vast majority of people take their responsibility seriously. They are the people I am most interested in. I regularly go down to the repossession courts to watch what is happening. I invite all of the committee members to go down to their local repossession court or to the one in Dublin to see the carry-on that takes place and how difficult repossession is. In my submission, I have outlined three case studies from last Thursday. There is no selection or bias here. These are three from last Thursday alone. I have set out the details. I will deal with one in particular. I am using the borrower's initials, SM. She is a Start Mortgages customer. She borrowed €267,000 in 2008 and today owes €350,000. The last time she paid was six years ago. She is not that unusual.

She is unrepresentative of mortgage holders in general but she is not unrepresentative of many mortgage holders who are before the courts and have orders granted against them. She had the usual two years or so of a mortgage arrears resolution process, when the banks were dealing with customers before getting anywhere near coming the heavy with them. She has been in the courts process for four years and her case has been adjourned on multiple occasions. She said she was going to go from mortgaging to renting and she got an adjournment on the basis that she would engage with MABS. However, she did not engage with MABS and it stopped representing her. She is investigating a personal insolvency arrangement and has excuse after excuse but she is paying nothing. It is the rest of us who are paying for her.
I would like vulture funds to be redundant. I do not particularly want to see them operating in this country but if we are not going to allow the banks to repossess houses, vulture funds are necessary. A bank repossessing a house with a mortgage with a nominal value of €100,000 would probably collect in the region of €80,000 if it were allowed to do so, with a 20% write-off in the process. If it sells the house to a vulture fund, it would get €50,000 or €60,000 so it loses money by doing so. It would be much better to allow the bank to repossess the house.
Having said all that, I want to see protection for responsible borrowers. Some vulture funds have been particularly aggressive in their dealings with customers. Many borrowers got into difficulties some years ago and have now recovered but if they had been with any other bank, their arrears would have been capitalised. They would pay a lot of capital and their mortgage would be paid off at or around their retirement, albeit at a later time than originally scheduled. They were being harried by the vulture funds, particularly Tanager, but that has now changed. Tanager has become much more open and is facing challenges of its own, including a High Court case with Rolf Kane and the discovery that it has been calculating repayments incorrectly. Tanager is now engaging fairly well with borrowers and they are getting good treatment from the company.
In a recent case in Galway which was written up on my website, askaboutmoney.ie, AIB initiated legal proceedings when the woman involved was €2,500 in arrears. If members were to go down to the courts, they would see that the biggest users of legal action, by any measure, are AIB and Permanent TSB. They would not see the vulture funds there too often.
A cohort of people cannot pay their mortgages, or are really struggling to do so, but are doing their best. In my view, they should be getting a mortgage assistance payment. If I cannot pay the rent on my home and I am either on social welfare or a low earner, I will get the housing assistance payment which will help me stay in my home. However, we do not give anything to borrowers and that makes no sense. If I cannot pay my mortgage, I get no assistance from the Department of Employment Affairs and Social Protection. If I sell my house to Mr. Hall and pay rent to him, however, the Department will give me housing assistance payments. A mortgage assistance payment would be very cheap for the Government to operate because, even at the higher rates of interest in Ireland, it is much cheaper to rent money than to rent property. This is at standard variable rates but at tracker rates the Department would be able to pay the mortgage in full - interest and capital - for less than its housing assistance payments to a fund that buys one of these houses under the mortgage-to-rent scheme. A mortgage assistance payment would help far more people, particularly as mortgage-to-rent is an extremely complicated way of dealing with things and the Department of Finance would be very reluctant to see its widespread use because it can never be reversed. Once my house is sold to a fund, it becomes social housing for life unless my situation changes and I can buy the house back at a discount.
In my appendix, I have included some of the figures for the number of mortgages in arrears and how many are family homes, on which I focus as distinct from commercial lending. There are 11,400 non-performing loans on the market. I was delighted that Permanent TSB pulled its split mortgages yesterday. The Central Bank and the Single Supervisory Mechanism have a crazy definition of non-performing mortgages and Permanent TSB had very profitable split mortgages which it was being forced to sell. I do not know what has happened and its explanations have been quite vague. I also list examples of what people have said about all this. Ulster Bank sold mortgages on 900 family homes a couple of years ago. All the loans were in the courts process but, despite that, the bank felt it was better and simpler to sell them because otherwise they would have been stuck in the process for number of years.
I would like the committee to focus on the bigger picture, which is the very high mortgage rates being charged because we do not allow banks to repossess. If we insist that banks are not to be allowed to repossess houses, we should not complain if the loans are sold to vulture funds.

I thank the Chairman, Deputies and Senators for the invitation to give evidence today in respect of loan sales. It may seem strange to say that it is a pleasure to be here but it is for one key reason. No other committee of these Houses recognises more clearly that it is the duty of Irish politicians to speak truth to power. No other committee is more clearly engaged in the key duty of Irish politicians to keep the people safe and that is what I wish to speak of here today. I acknowledge and remind everyone of the many people who are in arrears who are watching these proceedings. I say a particular "Hello" to my bank and to my vulture fund friends and their spokespersons.

The Irish Mortgage Holders Organisation, IMHO, is one of two registered national charities that advocate for and help people who are in debt. The fact that there are only two tells us a great deal in comparison with other sectors. We negotiate with creditors, informally and formally, via the Insolvency Service of Ireland, and we have an in-house personal insolvency practitioner registered with the service. We also provide a free bankruptcy service after all other options have been exhausted. A quarter of all those adjudicated as bankrupt last year were clients of ours.

Since our foundation in 2012, we have helped over 8,000 families, with 90% of them staying in their homes. I am speaking to the committee today with significant front-line experience of the actual challenges and not from any observer’s seat. The mental health of thousands of citizens has been and is suffering from the effects of being tortured by banks, creditors and a system that has protected banks, big corporations and developers but abandoned ordinary citizens. I am very proud of the work done by the IMHO team and board to date but, despite all of that work, I genuinely fear we have entered a dangerous stage in the mortgage arrears story.

We have seen this moment coming for a period. Recognising that many people left behind in mortgage arrears would lose their home, I and my fellow directors established iCare Housing, an approved housing body set up specifically to facilitate mortgage-to-rent. AIB, to its credit, fully supported us in establishing ourselves and has approved us for funding to buy homes. Much to our surprise, and perhaps that of AIB, they took a leap of faith but many more will be needed.

The involvement of a debtor advocate charity to help people via the IMHO has been of great help. We have cases involving 536 families - 2,300 people - in our pipeline and we expect to buy the first 99 homes next month. This change has transformed, and possibly even saved, lives and the combination of an approved housing body and the IMHO has been very positive.

I have included a copy of the enhanced mortgage to rent process, which was adopted and changed with the help of the Housing Agency, which has been exceptionally helpful in establishing iCare and moving things forward, and full details of the pipeline and all the various banks it represents to the committee ahead of today. All banks, including vulture funds, are participating in mortgage to rent with one notable exception. Bank of Ireland still refuses to write off the residual debt of those people eligible for social housing. Despite the fact that these people are absolutely goosed and have no money, the bank still resists writing off the residual debt. We work closely with all other debtor support organisations such as MABS, FLAC, Phoenix Project, StepChange and the Insolvency Service of Ireland along with the many personal insolvency practitioners throughout the country. We are proud to be part of this exceptional family that helps debtors in this country. I am delighted to be addressing this committee as I believe it is the strongest voice those in mortgage arrears have in this Oireachtas. This committee has seen at first hand the deception of banks and is probably the only forum in the State where bankers are regularly seen by the public to be held to account. This important work needs to be continued by the committee with the same vigour with which it has been pursued to date.

There has been much commentary from various quarters around loan sales to vulture funds. Many have commented on how vulture funds do good deals and the fact that they give write offs giving the impression they are warm and cuddly. This is rubbish. Vulture funds are a cancer on our society. They have one thing on their agenda and that is feasting on the carcases of those who suffered because of the gambling by banks. These are ordinary citizens whose lives collapsed when the crash hit, who lost jobs, who became ill, who lost relationships or who lost their lives. One of the greatest affronts to those citizens crucified by the recession was the Government’s willingness to sell them out to vultures. This included not only those in arrears but those with performing loans. When someone goes into mortgage arrears, their bank assesses them against its waterfall of restructuring solutions. These include capitalisation of arrears, term extensions, reduction in interest rate, split mortgages and voluntary sale for loss or silent repossessions. This waterfall allows for banks, albeit for their own benefit, to offer solutions that cost them the least amount possible. Yes, 119,000 restructures have taken place, which is very welcome, but the Central Bank recently reminded us that 15,000 of these have failed. Some of these are precarious solutions such as capitalisation of arrears. In spite of vulture fund lovers' statements, what is critical is the fact that vulture funds do not restructure loans. This point is simply not being understood. They buy to obtain the asset, sell it and profit. If someone wants to lose their home and have their debt written off then vultures are for them. If someone wants somewhere to live, they have a problem if they are in mortgage arrears and their loan is sold to a vulture fund. Vulture funds have no interest in our housing crisis, no interest in any of the stories of those affected and no interest in the people represented by members of this committee in their constituency clinics and in here. As practising politicians, each member has seen this at first hand. Anyone engaged in helping people in mortgage arrears knows this. Those on the side lines profiting from engaging with vultures will blindly support them. Those gurus who claim vultures adhere to contractual terms need to understand that nowhere in any contract does it require the loan owner to offer any restructuring or help. People with arrears have broken the contract and are out of contract. The contract does not exist leaving them exposed. While banks are horrible, out of a mix of legal, fiscal and social necessity and for reasons of PR, they must provide some solutions. By contrast, vultures are a social evil.

I could stay here all day giving examples of how nasty vultures are but, respectfully, the point has been missed. Vultures are a symptom of the failure of Government; the Department of Housing, Planning and Local Government; the Department of Finance; the Central Bank; and the banks. Across all of these self-interested groups, there has been a collective intended or unintended incompetence and-or conspiracy to ignore the fact that the majority of people cannot pay. Banks, Government and bank lovers have allowed a narrative to develop and in some cases, have assiduously fostered the narrative that those in arrears that have not been resolved are messers, strategic defaulters and non-engagers. This is not true. The majority of those in long-term arrears, a number which stands at 31,500 households, cannot pay. I have yet to see someone of sane mind voluntarily turn up to be executed yet some believe they should do so and turn up in a repossession court. Some read details dictated by banks' lawyers about people's non-engagement but very few affidavits are opened in court that state someone can actually pay. I now believe that 17,000 individual mortgage holders, which represents nearly 80,000 people or a Croke Park-full of citizens, will have their homes repossessed. This is because the banks have been complicit in hiding the human crisis and destruction that are ahead. They have hidden the fact that thousands of families simply cannot restructure their loans. They cannot make payments that even meet the Insolvency Service of Ireland requirements and are not eligible for mortgage to rent. This is a human crisis which has not been seen before and this is the actual issue rather than the vultures. The inability of people to pay is the critical issue that has been left behind for those in mortgage arrears.

The banks currently selling loans to vultures are being dishonest. They are cowards by not informing this committee of the severe challenges that exists with customers who have engaged and supplied their financial information but simply cannot pay. They have been vilified as non-engagers. This is simply not true. The banks are outsourcing their dirty work and the vultures will respond enthusiastically by repossessing homes. I believe banks have taken another gamble that it is easier to take the backlash of selling family home loans to vultures rather than the backlash that will ensue from the thousands of customers who cannot pay and whose homes they would have to repossess. Some naively say vultures have not shown any aggression but let us not forget banks have a six-year head start on vultures. Anyone who engaged with a vulture and who tells the truth will ask why they are overly excited about repossessing properties. No loan portfolio in the world performs as well as Ireland given property prices. Many vultures believe they will actually be able to flip on their loan portfolio without having to repossess a single house. Nowhere else in the world is equivalent with regard to house prices going up by 10%.

The banks currently selling loans to vultures are being dishonest. They are cowards by not informing this committee of the severe challenges that exists with customers - customers who have engaged and supplied their financial information but who simply cannot pay. They have been vilified as non-engagers. This is simply not true. The banks are outsourcing their dirty work to vultures who will respond enthusiastically by repossessing homes. I believe banks have taken another gamble that it is easier to take the backlash of selling family home loans to vultures rather than the backlash that will ensue from the thousands of customers who cannot pay and whose homes the banks would have to repossess. Some naively say that vultures have not shown any aggression. Anyone who engaged with a vulture who tells the truth will ask why they are overly excited about repossessing properties. There is no loan portfolio in the world that performs as well as Ireland is with property prices. Many vultures believe they will actually be able to flip on their loan portfolio without having to repossess one house. Nowhere else in the world do house prices go up by 10%.

In representing those in mortgage arrears on the front line, my job is to be truthful with the information we have and the people we represent. The tsunami is coming unless something is done. The data circulated ahead of this meeting showing 600 actual cases shows the challenges - the fact that people have no money and no time and that hidden behind this is ill health, separation, continued loss of employment and the passing of time. Unless steps are taken to establish a NAMA-type organisation that will ensure a debt for equity solution is imposed through the insolvency service or loans that can be managed through a NAMA-type organisation along with immediate reviews of the social housing qualification criteria, we will be walking blindfolded into a massive social crisis. This situation is now so grave that while bashing banks and vulture funds is therapeutic, it actually misses the key issue that 17,000 families, or 80,000 people, cannot pay their mortgages. If we look at the current homelessness list, we can quadruple it because, effectively, that is what is facing us. I thank the committee for its time.

I thank our guests for appearing before us and for facilitating us to appear together. I will be brief because, unfortunately, I have another scheduled event. I am interested in some of the commentary here, particularly with regard to vulture funds. Mr. Burgess said that every opportunity is being provided to these borrowers before the banks act the heavy, in Mr. Burgess's own words. He refers to himself as a consumer advocate. Obviously, these individuals about whom we are talking were consumers of a certain product. Is it not the case that his position is that the banks cannot repossess these houses so let us send them to the vultures and they will do the job for them? He also made the point that these individuals are likely to pay in respect of social housing so where does he expect these individuals to reside after the vultures put them out of their houses? Is this not greater than an issue of pure raw capitalism? Do we not have a duty as a society to provide housing and shelter to individuals and try to find solutions?

I agree fully that we as a society have an obligation to provide social housing and to help people. I do not think it is the job of the banks to provide housing to people who do not pay their mortgage. That is just my view. I just do not believe that is the role of the banks. If people are saying they cannot pay their mortgage and that, therefore, the bank should do nothing about it, I do not accept that. I do not think it is right to say that the banks should not be allowed repossess because there are no houses for these people to go to. Mr. Hall is forecasting a tsunami of 17,000 repossessions. I do not expect the level of repossessions to be that high but I would advocate that there should be about 10,000. I would like to see about 10,000 repossessions.
I am not suggesting-----
On what basis does Mr. Burgess want to see 10,000 repossessions?
Sorry?
On what basis does Mr. Burgess want to see 10,000 repossessions? What evidence does he have to suggest that?
There are 10,000 people who are more than five years in arrears. There are people who-----
That does not necessarily mean they are not paying anything.
That does not but it-----
Is it not the case that each one of those people could be paying the maximum their household can pay currently?
They could be paying something but for a person to get to five years arrears he or she must have had a long period of paying nothing or paying very little.

No. Let me tease out this point. Unless the bank dealt with arrears capitalisation, a person could have paid only half the mortgage repayment in the first of those five years because he or she may have lost their job. However, the borrower may have paid the full mortgage repayment for the subsequent four years, yet find himself or herself in the category that Mr. Burgess has said is five years in arrears because there has been no arrears capitalisation.

No. That is not what five years in arrears means. There are a few ways to reach five years in arrears. If a person pays nothing for five years, he or she will be five years in arrears. If a person pays half their mortgage repayment for ten years, he or she will be five years in arrears. That is what it means.

Let us look at the analogy. We will take a family who, as a result of both partners losing their jobs, have paid nothing or a small amount for two and a half years. They then make the full repayment for the next two and a half years or longer over a ten year period. In the statistics suggested by Mr. Burgess, this family's home should be repossessed at a point where they may be making their full mortgage repayments and may have been paying a proportion of their mortgage for a period.
I covered that in my opening statement. Has the Deputy received that?
I did.

I covered that in the statement. People who have historical arrears who are paying their mortgage at the moment - I referred to those who are paying 3% of the balance outstanding - should be protected.
I am trying to drill down into this. Where does Mr. Burgess come up with the fact that 10,000 people should lose-----
They are Central Bank figures.

-----possession of their houses given that we now know - and we both agree - those people who are five years in arrears can include many people who are making the maximum payment they can currently afford? It is not that these people are not paying a penny for five years.

There are three cohorts, including those who are paying their mortgage repayments in full who are not in arrears. There are also those who genuinely would pay if they could pay, but they cannot do so due to marital breakup and so on. I want to see the mortgage assistance payment paid to those people to help keep them in their homes. I am very clear about that. There are, however, people who are paying absolutely nothing. If a person had social housing-----
This is key. Is Mr. Burgess claiming there are 10,000 people who are paying absolutely nothing?

I am claiming there are about 10,000 people who have been totally irresponsible, who are paying nothing and who could pay something. If a person has social housing and is getting housing assistance-----
Where does that data come from? What is the source of the figure for 10,000 mortgage holders who are paying absolutely nothing?

We are aware that 24,000 mortgages are in arrears for more than two years. We are aware that many of those are, in my view, perfectly sustainable mortgages. These people are paying either in full, or they are paying the interest in full. We are aware that some 10,000 people have not paid for more than five years. I am down in the courts looking at the likes of these people, although in many cases they do not come in to the court. When they come into the courts they get adjournments and they pay nothing. If a person has-----
I just need to ask -----

-----social housing or if a person has housing assistance payment, and if he or she is on social welfare, that person is expected to pay between 15% and 20% of income towards the housing. There are lots of mortgage holders, however, who are paying absolutely nothing. I come from the same rough background as Mr. Hall and I want to help people who are trying.

I get that, and with respect to Mr. Burgess he has provided the committee with a solution with regard to the mortgage housing payment, but he is also arguing for sales to the vulture funds. The argument, put forward by many, is that we should not sell to the vulture funds because we need to come up with other solutions to try to deal with individuals who simply cannot afford to pay. Mr. Burgess is entitled to his opinion, with which I disagree strongly, but his commentary creates an atmosphere that makes it difficult to argue it as a consumer advocate position.

I must challenge Mr. Burgess on his point that 10,000 repossessions should take place. The witness repeated the figure in his reply when he said that in his view there are 10,000 people who are paying nothing. Can Mr. Burgess back up his assertion with any data provided by the Central Bank? In his response I ask that him not to refer to those people who are in arrears. It is very clear, as I believe we both understand, that the number of people who are in arrears does not equate with the figure of those who are paying absolutely nothing.
I have asked the Central Bank to publish the data around the numbers of people who are paying nothing. For some reason, the bank will not do this. Let us-----
Where does the figure of 10,000 people come from?

It is an estimate that can be worked out from the number of people who are in arrears for more than five years, and the number of people who have been in arrears for more than two years. One can then go down to see what is happening with repossessions in the courts. Let us assume that my figures are completely wrong and that there are only some 3,000 people who are paying absolutely nothing on their mortgage repayments. Let us say it is only 3,000. My solution of removing them from their houses should apply to those 3,000 people.
I will move on as I have limited time and my colleagues want to come in also.

Will Dr. O'Hagan-Luff comment on the proceedings around the legal difficulty in repossessions? Mr. Burgess presented the committee with three case files representing how the system is not working. In two of the cases orders were granted by the courts for repossessions. This may indicate that the system did work in the banks' favour in two out of three of the cases, despite the length of time that Mr. Burgess had argued. Is there a legal impediment to repossessions or is it the case that judges are being as flexible as possible given the social background and consequences of the housing crisis? This morning we heard stories of children and their parents being forced into Garda stations when they have had no accommodation. Is there a legal impediment that results in not repossessing?

I thank the Deputy for his question on legal impediment. I am not a legal expert so I cannot comment on that in any informed manner. I understand that the judges are in a very difficult position. They are trying to protect families and look after the most vulnerable. I understand that some of the repossessions that have occurred are of vacant or abandoned properties. Those would seem to be far less difficult cases. It is always a balancing act between showing compassion to the vulnerable in society and in creating a space where our mortgage system is seen as dysfunctional and would handicap future borrowers and the supply of new credit. I do not in any way suggest that those decisions are easy to make; they are not easy. There are hard choices between the hard luck cases on the one hand - where we would try to protect the vulnerable - and the other extreme where a decision could create the issue of moral hazard. If individuals think that contracts will not be enforced, it may reduce the discipline to repay in the future. It is a very delicate balancing act between those two forces.

I have made this point to Mr. Hall before, but again I thank his organisation for the assistance it provides to individuals and for the engagement I have had with it, as a public representative, on behalf of constituents. We get an insight into some of the detail of these cases. Other questions will be picked up by my colleagues, but I have one question about when an individual has failed to secure an agreement with his or her bank around a compromise solution. Mr. Hall pointed out that there are a suite of solutions and none of them has to be adhered to by any financial institution.
